718631f-a.text:
Charles Street, north side, from Washington to Greenwich Streets, showing the Sixth Precinct Police Station at No. 135 Charles Street.
November 8, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
AEE ~ E172
718631f-a.folder: Charles Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

724179f-b.text:
683, 681 & 679-77 (one story garage) Washington Street (left to right, across the foreground), at, adjoining and south of the S. E. corner of Charles Street, as viewed southeastward across a clearance on the west side of Washington Street, showing structures on a portion of the State Prison site of the early Nineteenth Century. Buildings on Charles Street bear No's. 146 to 134, the first being at the corner and having addresses on both thoroughfares. Partially shown on the right is the 12 story Everard Warehouse, occupying a site at the N. E. corner
of Washington and West 10th Streets.
No. 2 is similaw, tho slightly later.
November 8, 1930.
July 9, i932.
P. L. Sperr.
724179f-b.folder: Washington Street & Charles Street, Manhattan, NY

718619f-a.text:
Charles Lane (formerly Pig Alley), north side, west from, but not including, Washington Street. This little alley  runs east and west through the middle of the block bounded by West, Perry, Washington, and Charles Streets

April 18, 1931.
P.L Sperr

A more complete view, showing both sides. The dark outline shown are the pillars and elevated track way of the New York Central Railroad.

August 3, 1937.
P.L Sperr

156, 158 Perry Street, south side, west of Washington Street.
No. 158 is the one-story frame structure.
1932.

722557f-a.folder: Perry Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

724181f-a.text:
Washington Street, east side, from Charles to Perry Streets.
January 18, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
724181f-a.folder: Washington Street & Charles Street, Manhattan, NY

724182f-a.text:
Washington Street, west side, from Perry Street to West 10th (formerly Amos) Strect. The Beadleston & Woerz Brewery runs through the block from the south side of Charles Street to the north side of West 10th Street. In the foreground, Charles Lane (formerly Pig Alley) runs through the block, halfway between Perry and Charles
Streets, from Washington to West Streets.
This land on the west side of Washington Street, between Perry and Christopher Streets, was the site of the State Prison during the
first quarter of the nineteenth century.
July 30, 1932.
L. Sperr.
724182f-a.folder: Washington Street & Perry Street, Manhattan, NY

718620f-a.text:
Charles Lane, adjoining the N.W. corner of Washington Street, looking towards Perry Street. The little stable in the foreground is the easternmost building (there are no house numbers) on the north side of Charles Lane, and directly adjoined the rear of the six-story building at 694 Washington Street, which was demolished to make room for the New York Central elevated roadbed. The rear of 154 and 156 Perry Street, on the south side, is shown.
April 10, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
718620f-a.folder: Charles Lane & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

724177f-a.text:
Washington Street, west side, north from and including Charles Lane, showing the railroad's elevated roadbed under construction.
April 1O, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
724177f-a.folder: Washington Street & Charles Lane, Manhattan, NY

722556f-a.text:
143 and 141 Perry Street, north side, east of Washington Street (left, clearance at the N.E. corner). On the right, No. 139 formerly
stood.
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
722556f-a.folder: Perry Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

722558f-a.text:
Perry Street, north side, east from Washington Street, showing at the N.E. corner a clearance that will be improved by a 1-story garage. On Greenwich Street appears the Ninth Ave. Elevated Line.
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
722558f-a.folder: Perry Street & Washington Street, Manhattan, NY

Washington Street, west side, north from Perry Street.
September 24, 1930.

724184f-a.folder: Washington Street & Perry Street, Manhattan, NY

724185f-a.text:
Washington Street, east side, north from Perry (right) to West 11th Streets, showing a demolition at the N.E. corner of Perry Street that will provide a aite for a 1-story garage. The four story houses adjoining the clearance on the left will be included in this project. Appearing on the
right are Nos. 143 and 141 Perry Street. They will remain.
August 3, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
724185f-a.folder: Washington Street & Perry Street, Manhattan, NY
